Im sitting in line at the DMV in NY with my autistic son for 4 hours to get him an ID cArd. The USAs domestic identity process is quite in need of a new process as well.  The past two hours have been to pay an 8$ fee.
Sounds like a common problem. 4 hours is common here although that is only how long it takes after you enter the building. No accounting how long you may wait in line on the outside. :cry:

Fred nice to see you here, these bureaucratic inefficiencies don't just cost global taxpayers billions, when waiting 4 hours to pay an $8 fee, think of how much the gov lost too - you could have been working at x $'s per hour so that is missed opportunity for them as well in terms of tax revenue and lost economic productity towards your companies! I wonder what type of social impact projects - maybe even launched on IXO - will help solve such infrastructure challenges.
Hi everyone, nice to meet you, I am Steven Hatzakis, just wanted to say thank you also to @dafenster  for introducing me to this inspiring project.

I think these initiatives need to start at local levels. Building identity ground up from local levels, digitizing government payments and according. Estonia has been doing this with e-identity and digitizing the government (although not yet hugely useful if youre not a true Estonian citizen but only e-resident). Estonia is like a million people though - its a small city in US but if we can start small on local and municipal levels, thats where things can get traction. New York City dept of social services is exploring blockchain to tackle homelessness - kind of like a decentralized Airbnb that matches private landlords providing housing to the homeless with the city compensating the landlords - could be a block of apartments or a single spare bed. Blockchain creates the trust layer between parties that dont necessarily trust each other.

I was just thinking the same in terms of when people try to think of ways that they can create positive social impact, is to start with their local communities and indentify needs they are aware about and start there. Speaking of New York, a local gov official who has proposed several blockchain bills will be speaking at an event (I plan on going) https://tech2025.com/events/think-tank-6-ny-blockchain-legislation-and-the-creation-of-a-digital-currency-taskforce-with-assemblyman-clyde-vanel/#gettickets (and I think ID solutions like what Estonia did with their e-residency licenses is pretty cool.
Thanks for that! Lets go together!!

Quick intro: I''m working on a project to bring equal access to legal services. Law presents an interesting opportunity in that the professional and philanthropic efforts are very well aligned. I'm keen to connect with devs and lawyers in this space. Currently looking to recruit a strong tech lead.I'm in Cape Town & met with Lohan last week - will definitely be exploring further opportunity with ixo. Cheers!

Hey David I'm a lawyer! Tell me more about your work. Just before law school many moons ago I spent 5 months in Uganda setting up an NGO to provide legal services. I was looking at land titling - but this was before anyone was talking about blockchain applications :)

It's early days - the whitepaper is in mid draft - I met with Lohan last week he can give you more detail - in Law, there's a unique opportunity to directly fund an indexed input to philanthropy and the goal is different to most social good projects - justice demands you 'have' your day in court, not that you necessarily 'win'. I'm not a lawyer, I'm a start-up'er who loathes injustice. After learning the lesson the hard way, it began to fascinate me that justice should not be sought (or expected) in the law. In uneven society like ours in SA, this is exacerbated but it's obviously a global issue. We now have a tool to tackle this problem of productivity in justice - I'm pretty stoked about the opportunity.
Have you looked at decentralized arbitration and dispute resolution on the blockchain?
We don't want to do a Lawyer's job for them and it is a very 'decentralized' profession to start with - the opportunity is in doing what lawyers and law firms are not doing

Hi all, I'm Naoyuki, a London/Tokyo based post-doc in law, joining you thanks to the introduction by Asuka Uesaka. I've been studying on land grabbing/biopiracy issues under globalization and now interested in how recent developments in tech/blockchain can solve them, or more generally will change development policies/ protection of fundamental rights. Also pumped to spread the idea of impact investments in Japan. Cheers!
Welcome
Can you elaborate on how you would like to see development of policies and protection of rights utilizing block chain?

Hi thanks! That's difficult to say now. We legal scholars are just beginning to explore it. Obviously blockchain will make the implementation phase of development policies more effective without unnecessary costs and missing links btw goals and outcomes. But about other impacts I'll explore them in a due course
What do you think of blockchain technology in healthcare
Decentralization of medical records etc
Research clinical trials
Well though I'm not familiar but that sounds promising. Are you running any projects in healthcare?
Yes im running personal health record application for patients providing a comprehensive view of their medical records along with medical smart card. Working now with tangle network
Nice! Where are you based?
South Florida US but as know the disparity in healthcare is a global issue
Yeah definitely. Will touch base when I come across with sth relevant for you
Im also working on other projects utilizing blockchain technology

I think beyond just digitization and decentralization of the storage and data governance of medical records, whats hugely interesting is the application of blockchain in making and verifying attestations of patient behavior or patient compliance - this is super relevant in US healthcare system in incentivizing preventative healthcare behaviors that reduce medical costs. Using smart contracts, verified attestations of patient compliance and good preventive care could be linked to automatic financial incentive payments from health insurance companies.
Well said! Thats what Im currently working on thanks the triple aim the regulations have forced healthcare providers hand to attest and meet meaningful use but patients usually go unaccounted for.
Would love to learn more about your work and where ixo might be applicable.
Hi Fennie! Yes, I enjoyed de Soto's works as well as following discussions by, say David Kennedy, but didn't know abt his involvement in the Global Blockchain Business Council. Will check it up!

Blockchain governance is hugely interesting area and lawyers arent even thinking about it yet. Much of blockchain design eg around consensus algorithms is really law and economics as applied to computer science. When I was in Uganda, I discovered different tribal customs and conceptions of land rights - rather than being an individualistic right as we understand in western legal tradition, land rights in certain tribal areas is communal and based on usage/utilization rather than property rights as an extension of self. Communal governance of communal property rights as managed through blockchain governance is hugely interesting and I hope you can study that!
Well all know the disparity in healthcare is a global issue and abundance of resources go under utilize from lack of proper data and integrity.
Who determines usage/utilization? How are those metrics calculated.
This depends on the communities and custom. Is the land being cultivated, farmed or used as grazing??

There is a young scholars' event focusing on technology and fundamental rights in Brussels and I expect it to be my first opportunity to talk about Blockchain governance, and meet people with similar interests. I'll keep you posted!http://www.philodroit.be/Brussels-Global-Law-Week-2018?lang=fr
Yes please do!
Are those resources being utilized by community? Im trying ascertain if it stems out of a collectivist mentally or environmental stressors.

Both. If you study water rights in California and the West, where drought was frequent, youll see that its also based on usage/utility rather than pure property rights as an extension of self - and the American West is the emolument of the rugged individual!

Well speaking of drought there is a major drought in Cape Town, where most of the ixo team is based. Tracking water usage and water sharing in contested environments is a key blockchain use case - blockchain is an ideal use case whenever a trust layer is needed amongst parties that may be adverse.

So lets say Cape Town needs to increase its water supply by tapping into ground water and not just surface water which is running out - how do you fairly allocate, track and police usage amongst competing parties in a fair and transparent way?
Block chain ledger to track water usage and allocation may be one part of solution in creating transparency and sense of fairness
Okay I see so you can utilize the sensors in their equipment and can utilize geospatial analysis and engineering. I recently have a presentation to oil industry

Yes - IoT sensors, independent data feeds and data oracles, big data, etc are all part of the key ingredients that can feed into the ixo network in making claims and verifying claims about impact and other real world events.

Hi Ali. Im Shaun, the founder of ixo and a physician. Your question about how the ixo protocol could be applied in healthcare is really close to my heart. We are preparing to implement some trials of various health use-cases with industry players and a startup in the US, though still early days. Yes, ditto question, Paras. It holds especially if these evaluation oracles are being claimed by Shaun to just 'evolve' (oracles taking shape & structure) in the typical undirected sense of the word. Am I the only one who doesn't trust Darwinian or Dawkinsian 'evolutionary' logic here related to blockchain? It seems out of place to use this language with timestamped videos as if depicting 'biological change' with analogy to human beings and our technologies in this case were enough. The globalising logic of blockchain for 'development' (i.e. SDGs) is preferable to Western, Victorian England-style evolutionary 'struggle' motif. In any case, I'm a development rather than evolution guy when it comes to blockchain distributed ledger technology. :blush: Perhaps others feel the same about focus on development or would rather wish to defend Darwin & /or Dawkins their ability to be experts & influencers in blockchain space?

In the context of evaluation oracles specifically - I can give a real life example that UNICEF is working on. Unicef is asked to evaluate whether schools in Kazakhstan are using the internet which believe it or not would require them to hire dudes on motorbikes to go to each school to check whether the modems are running on periodic basis. UNICEF can receive data feeds from Telefonica cell tower pings as well as some school mapping data from the government. It may also receive social media activity information from Facebook. If we use these data sources as part of our on chain evaluation audit trail, these would all be oracles and their credentials would be authenticated. UNICEF can use an algorithm to triangulate the data from these various oracles to determine whether schools in a region are using the internet, how much and how frequently.
The better your data the better the evaluation algorithms.

A simple evaluation algorithm can look at patterns and discrepancies in the claims. In the case of the food rescue, it would be looking at patterns of claims from the grocer, claims from the rescuer including attachment of receipts and receipt details. These patterns can also be discerned from the metadata of these claims eg when and where these claims were made, who is making the claims, along with the substance of the claims eg quantity of food, or kinds of food donated, etc.
Fantastic example of UNICEF. Im was wondering whether any theoretical / academic work has been done on this topic? I think a statistician can bring rigour to the method

All great questions and comments on the topic of Evaluation Oracles! Lets take a step back and define what we mean by an Evaluation Oracle. These fulfil an agent role in the ixo protocol. Agents can be humans, machines, DApps, algos... or groups of these in combination and/or in consensus (including BFT consensus) mechanism. A more complex example could be of a crowd forming their opinion on a claim, using a token curation staking mechanism to give their preferred algorithm higher ranking as the evaluation algo of choice. All evaluation agents in the ixo protocol have their own unique Decentralised Identifier (DID) with an associated reputation credential. Over time, reputation increases or decreases, depending on how well the agent is found to perform its function (for instance, based on number of uses, frequency of disputed claims ...). As far as evolving - we would hope that all agents (Human and Algorithmic) will learn over time, through data feedback.   @dafenster has described this quite well. When I speak about evolution, I mean this in a deterministic, Bayesian sense, where the algo gets updated with data and calibration against extrinsic references.
We will be putting our data science and research capabilities and partnerships in place, as a high priority, once we are funded. Any offers of advice, connections, referrals would be appreciated!

Also Ill be curious to know how you are thinking about updating reputation for evaluators. It brings us to the question of who polices the police :) Any system that can be gamed will be gamed. So my approach would be to refrain from crowd sourcing or algos for evaluation to start with. Let humans with reputations do it evaluation transparently and publicly. And let people debate with a human (who should be open to learn)
So in good wastages case, all videos and evaluation should be public and people can spot errors and correct them
But have someone reputable state their reputation

Hi Paras! All good points - theres a few considerations and difficult problems that people are actively working to resolve: 1) privacy and 2) incentivization (while punishing bad actors) for correcting errors or for commenting on reputation

The privacy issue is a big one - you may have heard of terms like zero knowledge proofs, which refers to a technique that allows a response to a query that is limited to that query only. A classic example would be going to a bar and you need to show your ID to be 21 or older (at least in America). Instead of showing your entire ID, all the response needs to return is a yes or no to the age 21 query - not even your full birthdate (not necessary) and certainly not your height and weight and address and ID number. Ideally, answers to multiple and varied queries should not be correlated back to a single identity to preserve privacy.

Privacy is particularly important under new data privacy laws in the EU - you may have heard of GDPR in the EU which is a regulation that says individuals have rights to ask publishers of personal identifying information (PII) to remove them. GDPR wasnt written with blockchain in mind so its a nice legal mind game - if PII is published on a public blockchain that is immutable, then what happens and who is responsible (miners, developers?) and what if public keys are considered PII (because it may be possible to correlate enough info to know who those public keys belong to)?
Agreed. Yep, privacy is a big issue here. Thanks for highlighting

Yes, and on the incentives part - thats where applications of token curated registries are interested as these registries use token economics to incentivize stakeholders in the outcome of that registry ranking to rank honestly (gains of winning a majority outcome outweighs the gains of being bribed).

Its useful where subjective opinions matter and so far AI cannot answer - how good was the food? How adequate was the cleanup of an oil spill in a way that restored community structure and engaged community stakeholders?
https://www.coindesk.com/icos-iced-12-month-freeze-us-token-trading-just-beginning/amp/

Ah yes - its a bit of a misleading title. What the 12 month freeze refers to is that under a Reg D security exemption, as a restricted security you cant just resell it immediately unless you are a broker dealer. So if youre not a broker dealer, Rule 144 gives you safe harbor to resell restricted securities if you hold on to them for 12 months, thereby demonstrating that you didnt buy the securities with an intent to immediately resell.
